Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 6. The Birth
The Bodhisattva spent ten months in the womb.
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): ཁང་བཟང་དེ་དང་མ་འབྲེལ་བར་བར་སྟོང་ཡོད་ཙམ་དུ་གཞན་ཞིག་ཏུ། ལུམ་བུའི་ཚལ་དེ་སྐྱེད་མོས་ཚལ་ཤིང་སྣ་ཚོགས་ཡོད་པ་གཅིག་བྱ། དེ་ན་འཁོར་མང་པོས་སྐོར་ནས། རང་ཡུམ་ཉིད་ཁྱོགས་བྱམས་ཁྲི་ལ་གཡོག་མ་འགའ་རེ་དང་བཅས་པ་ལུམྦི་ནའི་ཚལ་དུ་འབྱོན་པའི་ཚུལ་དང་། ཚལ་དེར་སྐུ་བལྟམས་པའི་བཀོད་པ་སྤྱི་དང་འདྲ་བ་ལས། ནམ་མཁའ་ནས་ཆུ་རྒྱུན་གཉིས་དབུའི་སྟེང་དུ་འབབ་པ་དང་། ལྷ་རྣམས་ཀྱི་གདུགས་དང་རྔ་ཡབ་ལ་སོགས་པ་མཆོད་པ་སྣ་ཚོགས་པ་འབུལ་ཞིང་།  ཚལ་དེའི་ཕྱི་ནང་ཐམས་ཅད་འོད་ཀྱི་ཁྱབ་པ་མཚོན་བྱེད་དུ། ཕྱི་ནས་འོད་ཀྱི་དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ཟླུམ་པོས་སྐོར་བ་འབྲི། དེ་དང་ཉེ་བའི་ཕྱོགས་རྣམས་སུ། རྒོད་མ་རྟེའུ་འབྲེང་པ་མང་པོ་དང་། གླང་ཆེན་མོ་ཕྲུག་གུ་འབྲེང་བ། བུད་མེད་ཁྱེའུ་དང་བུ་མོ་ཐོགས་པ་དང་། ས་འོག་ནས་རིན་པོ་ཆེའི་གཏེར་ཁ་བྱེ་བ་རྣམས་ལྔ་བརྒྱ་མཚོན་བྱེད། ལྔ་ཙམ་རེ་འབྲི།
Manual - English: In the open space near the mansion is Lumbini Grove (lum bu’i tshal / lum+bi ni’i tshal), a garden with a great array of trees. A large retinue is there. The queen sits in a palanquin and goes to Lumbini Grove with her entourage of maids. The birth of the Buddha takes place in the grove. The scenes should be drawn in accord with common conventions (spyi dang ‘dra ba). But, there should be two streams of water flow down onto the head. Gods offer many gifts such as parasols and tail fans. Light fills up both inside and outside of the grove. A ring of light surrounds the grove. Nearby is a scene of mares followed by colts, elephants with cubs, and women with baby boys and girls.  Five kinds of treasures are drawn to make up for deposits of five hundred kinds of treasures uncovered in the ground. In another mansion, (representatives of) vassals prostrate and offer gifts to King Śuddhodana.

Sun of Faith - English: The waxing moon of the final spring month arrived. The trees and flowers were in bloom. The birds were singing pleasant song. The mango trees were laden with ripe fruit.
Mahamaya Devi thought, "I should be in the gardens of Devadaha."
She asked the king and he gave his permission. She prepared to go to Lumbini grove near the city of Devadaha.
A palanquin studded with four kinds of jewels was prepared.
She was surrounded by her female attendants, together with king Shuddhodana and four banners of the king's guard.
They departed Kapilavastu and set out for Lumbini.
Other sutras say [the Buddha] was born early on the eight day, during the first foot of the constellation Pushya.
At any rate, his mother Mayadevi looked all around the garden, and saw a plaksha tree blooming with flowers.
She grasped a branch with her right arm. When she wished to give birth,
Indra thought, "This mother is modest. I need to do something!" So he raised violent wind and rain, and because of this the people ran away.
Inscription - English: Indra raised a violent wind and rain storm upon the men

Sun of Faith - English: Indra himself remained by her side in the guise of an old nursemaid.
And without causing any pain to his mother, the Bodhisattva was born.
He opened the right side of his Mother's waist and emerged. He was born like someone opening a door, passing through to the other side, and closing the door.
There was no trace of a visible scar.
Scene working notes: This is not in either of the accounts (Abhiniṣkramaṇa-sūtra Vinayavastu: Saṃghabhedavastu)

Sun of Faith - English: Indra began to hold the Bodhisattva's body with an animal skin blanket.
But the Bodhisattva transformed into a diamond body in order to deflate Indra's arrogance.
Indra was unable to hold him, and started to tremble.
"Kaushika, let me go!" said the Bodhisattva.
The Bodhisattva was modest, so to cover himself he dressed in divine garments and did not go naked.
As soon as he was born the earth trembled six times,
Scene working notes: The Vinayavastu source mearly mentions that the earth shakes with mention of how many times: "sa chen po 'di yang g.yos par gyur" (280b.1-2)

Sun of Faith - English: and a great light pervaded every region of the world.
At that moment, he took seven steps in each of the four directions and said,
“This is the east. I will go to the forefront of nirvana.
This is the south. I will be the object of veneration of all beings.
This is the west. This is my final rebirth.
This is the north. I will cross over the ocean of existence."
Two streams, one hot, one cool, fell from the heavens upon his head and cleansed his body.
Inscription - English: The gods bathe him and make offerings

Sun of Faith - English: The gods offered him a white parasol, a yaktail fly-whisk, incense, flowers, and clothes.
Scene working notes: In the Vinayavastu passage, the white parasol and (two) "jewel-handled yaktail fly wisks," are not given to the Bodhisattva, but, rahter, held over his head: "de'i dbu'i steng nas lha rnams gdugs dkar po dang / rnga yab nor bu'i yu ba can dag 'dzin to/" (280b.6)

Sun of Faith - English: Music sounded forth.
A large spring appeared before the Bodhisattva's mother and she bathed herself.
Inscription - English: The mother bathes in a spring

Sun of Faith - English: The light rays from his birth reached the cave on Mount Sandhara where the sage Asita was meditating with his nephew and disciple Naradatta.
Scene working notes: In the Vinayavastu passage there is no mention of "meditation" per se, although it describes them as: " 'jig pa la mkhas pa/ 'chags pa la mkhas pa zhig gnas te/" (280a.7-281b.1)

Sun of Faith - English: Seeing the cave filled with light, Naradatta asked "Has every single sun risen at once?"

Asita said, 
"The sun's rays are ever sharp.
My son these rays of light
Feel cool and pleasing to the touch.
They must be light rays from a sage."
Naradatta suddendly wished to see the Bodhisattva.
Asita said, “Right now famed powerful gods surround him, so we will not have any chance. When he arrives in Kapilavastu we will go to see him.”
On that day, sons were born to the kings of the four directions.
Without considering that the world was filled with light rays from the new-born body of the Bodhisattva, [the kings] thought it came about by virtue of each of their sons.
Mahapadma, king of Magadha, named his son Bimbisara (Essence of Form).
Mahakoshala, king of Shravasti, named his son Prasenajit (Acquiring Clarity) .
Shatanika, king of Kaushambi, named his son Udayana (Rising Sun).
Anantanemi, king of Ujjayini, named his son Pradyota (Dazzling).
They were named after a feature of the light pervading the world.

On the day that the Bodhisattva was born, five hundred Shakya boys such as Bhadrika were born. Five hundred Shakya girls were born. Five hundred boys such as Chandaka were born to the King's servants, and five hundred girls such as Shabha were born to the female servants.
Five hundred elephants had calves. Five hundred mares had foals.
Inscription - English: Babies were born to five hundred she-elephants, five hundred mares, and five hundred she-camels

Sun of Faith - English: Five hundred treasures were discovered.
The vassals of the region offered tribute.
Inscription - English:
The vassals of the region pay tribute

Shuddhodana

Sun of Faith - English: The king said, “With the birth of my son, all my wishes have been fulfilled. So I shall name him Siddhartha, "All Aims Accomplished.” And so he was known.
